instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Hello ,

I got this Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  was previously water damaged and was repaired by me , last week the owner brought it saying that its not charging and not booting  , so I have checked it and on my AMP meter i am getting 5.09V      , 1.01 watts and 0.20 amps . So I proceeded to open it and take a quick look inside and all was looking fine .So I pulled out the board and connect my amp meter and placed the board under my thermal imager and found that <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> was getting super hot , so I ordered <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> on eBay since i did not have any donor boards here to harvest it from , I received the chip on Friday and I installed it Yesterday and the behavior did not change . Since after I changed <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> with the new chip that I ordered <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> The T2 along with <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> they get hot but still no 20V on my USB amp meter and no boot , I have checked all  the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> Chips  and I have even changed the whole 4 of them which  I did not even have to but did it just in case , now I m wondering if my <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> new chip can be bad as the seller would allow only one chip per order so i was able to get only one chip of <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> . <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is Present.

Please Help me out.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Its a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Changing a chip because geting hot???
Usually heats because of overcurrent, caused by OTHER component.

Didn't even check its output voltage?
What about diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: I forgot to mention that , That was the first thing that I did ,  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> before I removed  the chip was short to ground Diode mode was . then as soon as I remove the chip the short was gone then after I replace the new chip  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>  in diode mode was 0.311    and  measuring <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> voltage i am getting 12.28

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
12.28V on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> for sure???
The board must be trash in such case.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
I have another good board the same type also when i measured  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>   I am getting 12.65V, I wonder if my new <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>  that I ordered on eBay is working. Any other suggestions? 

Thank you very much.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
No idea how can you get such voltage on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>.
Did you really check on correct point?
What about L6900/01 voltage?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
I was also shocked too  as i was expecting 3.3v there  and that was why I got my known good board to compare voltages and the good working one was giving me 12.65V  

L6900 and 6901 is giving me 3.373V

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
P3V3G3HRTC_FB  = 0.869V

P3V3G3HRTC_SS  = 0.869V

I am going to rerun the voltages again , but I am having a very strong feeling that my <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> that i got from Ebay maybe is not a genuine chip , I don't wanna pull it from my other good working board as I keep them to compare voltages when they come in with problem , On rossmangroup store t <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is not listed , do you have any other suppliers where i can get those from and Quick?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
"L6900 and 6901 is giving me 3.373V"
What's the problem then, why do you want to change <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> again???
Isn't <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> coming from these coils?
I cannot understand how do you got 12V before...

PLEASE, try to understand a schematic and post ACCURATE information.
We can't help if your replies are "out of range"...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Ok , Sorry If I did not clearly express that  but  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_REG_R</SIGNAL> to me they are two different power rails from my point of view ,

And I can see  L6900 and 6901  is connected to the power rail   <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_REG_R</SIGNAL> is providing 3.373V  , but  the 12.28V that I mentioned in  my earlier message  is  coming from PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3HRTC_R . I am going to post of the diode mode and voltages of <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Don't bother anymore with <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> if you indeed get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>.

All AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages present?
Check LDO voltages for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.message: Ok, let me check that.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
All AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages is present and normal

When I Check LDO voltages for <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.  I found <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>  , 3200, as well as UB300  <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>  0.000,    without voltages while all the other voltages are present , that same   <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> diode mode reading is 0.486  However at UB400  <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> is present and normal , Help me to proceed please.

threads.message: I forgot to mention that  All the 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chps  Have been replaced by new ones .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
1V1 LDO appears only on the powered port!
Check it again.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Is <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> the power port Or UB400? Cause I only  get 1v1 at UB400 please advice.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
With power port I mean USB-C connector.
Each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip corresponds to a different power port...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Understood, I am getting 1v1 at UB400 and all the other LDO Voltages are normal, but i am still stuck at  5.09V on my USB amp Meter.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Did you check if any other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip gets corresponding 1V1 LDO, when connect charger on its port?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: All the other ones are giving me 0.000  only UB400 Giving me the correct 1V1

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Then you have a problem on USB-C areas related with the other chips.
Compare diode mode readings around these with UB400.

I hope UB400 doesn't get 1V1 LDO when you connect charger to another port...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: That Macbook got wet very badly ,  It seems to be a layer issue, cause i can feel when i place the probe to run test around the area of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>  if i press the area,  around  feels like a sponge like its bouncing back and forth , I think that i will just hand it back to the customer. I have fixed a good bit of those with that same issue and never had to face that kinda issue before .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: UB400 doesn't get 1V1 LDO when you connect charger to another port
